title: Will Apple's iPhone net sales be higher in FY 2021 than FY 2019?
preds:
They did it in 3 quarters: Q1 65.6M (https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/27/apple-aapl-earnings-q1-2021.html)
Q2 47.94M (https://www.cnbc.com/2021/04/28/apple-aapl-earnings-q2-2021.html)
Q3 39.57M (https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/27/apple-aapl-earnings-q3-2021.html)
Total: 153.11M

https://s2.q4cdn.com/470004039/files/doc_financials/2021/q3/FY21_Q3_Consolidated_Financial_Statements.pdf Well, they haven't posted the 10-Q yet, but if the numbers from this Financial Statement are final, they've officially beaten 2019 ($142.381 Billion) in 3 quarters ($153.105 Billion).
Middle class consumers have mainly saved money through the pandemic; on the other hand, global supply chain shortages may delay launch and limit supply of new iphones at end of 2021
iPhone sales have reached a ceiling, but the whole smartphone market is still growing especially in emerging economies
5G technology tends to boost the sales

Much of the year already baked in with new model doing well. Underlying structural growth over a long period but possibility of problems on either supply or demand side with US-China relations, also delta COVID variant.

Against: IPhone 12 didn't make a big splash. Latest ios is low key. Biggest sales occur over Christmas period.
For: yet more helicopter money in the US and people love their iPhones!
Already seeing strong Q1 numbers, and potential for updated model in H2 of this year to stoke demand
No. The newest iPhone has not made any waves with non-phone leasers and business contracts aren't signing up for new phones since travel is down
As of the start of this summer there are microchip shortages , due to covid relates mining slow down , but only due to mass sales earlier in year and end of last year...
With recovery coming back and e-commerce penetration higher, believe it will be strong. The decline in 2020 was temporary.
Looks like annual reports already show big increases, as per @Terry-Smith 's forecast

It's way higher now than it was at this point in 2019. 
Please see page 8 for 2021 year to date: https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/320193/000032019321000056/aapl-20210327.htm
Page 8 for 2019 YTD: https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/0000320193/000032019319000066/a10-qq220193302019.htm
Market is at saturation. People are not replacing their Iphones so quickly.

iPhone 12 build is said to be at high production levels, and the average price is said to be high with more pro and pro max orders. 
iPhone sales are still ~70% of Apple's revenue.
Because of Covid restrictions and lockdown most people have more money to spend and want to make « rewarding » expensive shopping
Supply chain problems, market market saturation
I got a feeling that the new iPhone will be something better than 2019.

Despite global economic downturns most of the contractions are in the services market, not consumer goods. There was huge spike in "people needing tech" following lockdowns and I imagine much of that carried into 2021.

En primer lugar, la pandemia a tenido un fuerte efecto sobre las cadenas de suministro, y por lo mismo ha generado problemas para conseguir partes y piezas así como para distribuir los productos ya terminados. Esto se ha traducido en mayores costos de distribución y una evidente ralentización de los procesos.
Por otra parte, tenemos el efecto ecnómico sobre los consumidores. La mayor parte de la población ha recibido un duro impacto a su nivel de ingresos, por lo tanto, se esperaría una reducción importante en el consumo de artículos no escenciales, entre ellos los iPhones.
Si bien los procesos de vacunación han avanzado con rapidez y actualmente Estados Unidos está administrando 3.3 milllones de dosis al día. De acuerdo al simulador de Reuters, recién para Octubre de 2021 toda la población estadounidense habría recibido la 2da dosis. Esto deja un margen muy cerrado para que la economía alcance a recuperarse durante este año.
Por otro lado, tenemos la relación de EEUU con China. Ya que, por un lado, el gigánte asiático, que pareciera haber controlado completamente la pandemia, es un gran consumidor de Iphones, lo que podría considerarse una buena noticia para Apple. Sin embargo, actualmente existe una guerra comercial entre ambos países (recordemos en caso de Huawei) y China ya ha dado muestras de que puede tomar contra medidas en respuesta a las restricciones que le ha impuesto el país americano. Dados todos estos argumentos, y sumado al hecho descrito en la descripción del problema (de que la pandemia ya tuvo un efecto negativo sobre la venta de iPhones durante el 2020) creo que hay 0% de probabilidad de que durante el 2021 esta situación se revierta.
Negligible probability this does not occur.
Wall Street expects Apple to deliver about 220 million iPhone units in 2021. iPhone 12 seems to run.
2019 was a down year; 2021 looks like it will be a record.
+5 to follow the crowd a bit. Not sure if the confidence is warranted so early in the year, but there are good reasons to think this will happen.

You know I have an iPhone. I like it. Will probably get another one one day. But COVID has really hit people’s pocket books. I won’t say an iPhone is discretionary income it’s a good unit but we are talking about the impact of COVID on the economy as a whole.  On another note watch out for those short sellers over inflating expectations. Looking to make a buck could be foreign influence. Maybe I’m just paranoid.

Net iphone sales were 65 billion for quarter 1 which is up 10 billion from 2020. 2020 was down a little from 2019. Going up 10 on that. https://www.businessinsider.com/apple-earnings-q1-2021-revenue-iphone-eps-profit-analysis-2021-1

Record sales of iPhones in the previous quarter indicate that Apple will likely have a successful year. Second quarter numbers will be critical to see if Apple can maintain this pace. https://internationalbanker.com/brokerage/apple-posts-record-quarterly-revenues-as-iphone-sales-surge/

Bumping up my initial forecast following strong Q1 numbers from Apple that were particularly driven by iPhone sales. The introduction of the iPhone 12 during the last quarter helped to fuel record quarterly revenue for Apple. Q1 sales for this quarter far outpaced those during the same time of FY19 giving Apple a good head start to see an increase in iPhone net sales following another decline in FY20. Additionally, strong global sales, especially in China and India, buoy the possibility of strong FY21 sales.

Likely strong upgrade cycle in much of the world - as much about number of models & cameras as 5G. 
However, there are variables from demand in China (especially if any retaliation against various measures such as Huawei bans), plus any sudden economic fall-out from Q1'21 onwards
Apple is taking share from Huawei

Revised forecast: Apple has announced it is seeing increased demand for its new iPhone. This has lead them to increase their forecast for 2021 including ordering 96 million phones for the first half of 2021 and the possibility of building 230 million phones for the entire year. This represents an increase of 20% over 2019 figures. Worth keeping an eye on but after several years of declining production, it appears Apple is set for a rebound in 2021.

IPhone12 is said to have battery issues.
I assume this might cause delays in deliveries.
iPhone sales have been declining since 2015. I expect this trend to continue. People misunderstand Apple as a business. They think it wants to be Ford when it actually wants to be BMW.
extremizing and guarding for atm unlikely delays due to global economic downturn or delays
Won't have more clarity until the first 10-Q, but by all accounts the iPhone 12 has been a huge seller, and it's all pushed into FY '21.

Currently, iPhone unit shipments are predicted to be around or about 230 million in fiscal 2021, with expectations for about 86 million to 87 million units to be shipped in the December quarter. This would mean a 20% year-over-year increase in unit shipments, resulting in fiscal 2021 revenue and EPS that are well above the consensus. Coupled with the decreasing cost of iPhone XR, 11, and introduction of an iPhone 12 - mini, there are plenty of options for buyers, especially if the globe begins to emerge financially sound from the COVID-19 pandemic.

Privacy activists noyb ("none of your business") have sued Apple for alleged privacy breach and wants to force the company to remove their Identifier for Advertisers (IDFA) from their appliances, esp. iPhones. IDFA is automatically generated when the iPhone is installed for the first time - without knowledge or consent of users. Although not directly linked to turnover or profit of Apple and their iPhone business, this lawsuit could delay any delivery of appliances - newest or older generations - to European consumers, since Apple would have to either ask the user for consent or remove the IDFA routine from their European iOS version. I wonder if millions of iPhones would be marketable as planned without update at all.
https://www.spiegel.de/netzwelt/web/apple-aktivisten-reichen-beschwerde-wegen-werbe-tracking-auf-iphones-ein-a-5a83891e-e811-4e23-b201-82809c460508 noyb is known for taking up fights with big adversaries: facebook/Mark Zuckerberg, and Privacy Shield. 
They won.
Natural growth + bounce back from 2020's downside.

Apple is encountering challenges with supply chains and if the global economy continues to suffer due to covid, people won’t have the money to buy iPhones while they can buy cheaper high quality phones.  Their iPad market may go higher.

- According to Bloomberg, Apple Inc. has asked suppliers to build at least 75 million 5G iPhones for later this year, roughly in line with last year’s launch, which means that despite the pandemic situation they expect to have at least the same levels of sales than the previous year.
- While the Covid-19 outbreak has worsened the global economy, Apple is having a strong demand for iPhones, iPads and Mac computers from people working and studying remotely.
- Despite this, I don't think that the revenues will be higher than those got in 2019.

FY 2019 appears to have been consistent with the average since FY 2016 - ~$140B. Spikes in the last couple of years have been in FY 2018 and FY 2015.  I have not been able to unpack whether the models released in those years corresponded to models with significant feature upgrades. I am going to make an educated guess and say that is probably true - happy to be corrected :-). That would point to the first 5G IPhone causing a similar spike. The complicating factor of course is COVID. However even with the COVID hit in FY 2020 there was only a 3% hit to sales - it wasn't catastrophic. If we had a similar hit next year, but the ~say 10% boost from the new model (it was 18% in FY 2018), we would still be ~4% above FY2019. I see that as a decent margin of error. Regarding the probability estimate I would say I am confident it is greater than 60-40, but not as high as 90-10. Something around 70-30, and 80-20 seems right.  Because of the small risk of supply disruption I will go for the lower value
Thanks to @DNK89 for giving the sources informing this prediction.

I personally do not think IPHONE sales will be higher than FY 2019 because of supply chain issues because of the COVID 19 and economic issues globally. Significant economic growth this last quarter took place in China and I think IPHONE sales will do well in that area but sales will be flat in the rest of the world. The last factor is this newly released phone does not feature exciting new advancements and I do not think that will drive consumers to upgrade their current phones.

Factors to consider 1> Replacement cycles slowing down 
Apple has acknowledged in the past that overall replacement cycle for the Iphone has been slowing down. Probably as newer phones lack a significant upgrade in features which would cause people to defer replacing their phones. Apple knows this and even after the 4 launches this year the average selling price of its Iphones will still remain the same (Refer Q4FY20 earnings transcript link at the end)
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/02/08/apple-iphone-replacement-cycle-slowing-toni-sacconaghi-says.html
2> 5G
There is some optimism that 5G is expected to drive demand for Iphones however throughout most of the world excl China. 5G is still being rolled out. This is the reason some are expecting the start of a new replacement cycle in this year.
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/12/americans-might-not-be-able-to-take-full-advantage-of-the-5g-iphone-.html
3> China
China accounts for 15% (used to account for 20% 2 years ago) of OVERALL revenues. Trends here look good as currently 1 out of every 2 phones sold is a 5g enabled phone. Also Huawei which accounts for 45% of the smartphone market is facing chip shortages
https://www.counterpointresearch.com/china-smartphone-market-declines-14-yoy-q3-2020-50-smartphones-sold-5g-capable/
4> Impact of the pandemic 
We are in a pandemic and that should ideally increase the replacement cycle also they are still facing some headwinds on ramping up their supply chain(reported in latest earnings call). While growth in retail sales has been surprisingly good last year. will this sustain(depends on how much more of job loss we might see and stimulus packages)
https://www.fool.com/earnings/call-transcripts/2020/10/30/apple-aapl-q4-2020-earnings-call-transcript/ Summing everything up
The base still remains favorable, we might see 2 launches in the current year(assuming next year`s launch doesnt get delayed) and the ask rate of revenue growth required for a Yes to this question is very low, however believe that there will be some rationalization in discretionary spends going forward. Sitting on the fence for now.

Because iPhones are a thing and people buy on credit regardless of their circumstances. Plus, they often think the phones are free despite paying for them on credit (also free) every month. Take a look at At&t ads, " iPhone 12 on us" cuz were just good guys.

i phone sales have been declining in the last few years and the most recent quarter again showed depressed sales figures. Apple is seeing an increase in tablet and laptop sales due to the pandemic. THe 2019 levels were among its lowest since 2014, so the bar is not as high as it has previously been but all signs point to a disappointing sales number.

FY21 sell-side consensus I see looks to be well above $142 bln with. 80% may be on the low side given new iPhone models, pricing and China demand, but starting here given where we are and lack of initial research.

The delayed Iphone 12 release is a big factor that makes this seem fairly likely. The 2020 report says "iPhone net sales decreased during 2020 compared to 2019 due primarily to the absence of new iPhone models in the fourth quarter of 2020 and the weakness in foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar, partially offset by the introduction of iPhone SE in the third quarter of 2020." The IPhone 12 released in late October, later than usual annual mid-September release. Apple's Q4 ends on the last Saturday of September. Normally the first few days of the new release gets counted in Q4. This year it missed Q4 entirely, so that likely means Q1 of FY 2021 will be larger than normal. That seems to me to be likely to set FY 2021 on track to be larger than FY 2019 (FY 2020 was only 3% down from 2019). I don't know how big the bump from those first few days is but I'd guess since Apple cites it as one reason 2020 was 3% down from 2019 instead of exceeding 2019 that it's maybe 2% of FY 2019 or so. Not large but gives 2021 a slight advantage going in. Since the effect of those numbers ending up in Q1 may be small I also looked at the Iphone sale history. It looks like it's a general upward trend with a recent plateau over the last few years. It seems like most of their decreases come after boom years, otherwise the trend is somewhat steadier. So eyeballing based on that and the delayed Iphone 12 I think an increase is more probably than not. Release dates of previous Iphones: https://www.iphonelife.com/content/evolution-iphone-every-model-2007-2016 Data and chart for Iphone sales since 2013 (2013 picked arbitrarily): https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1F_Ug-60gdwwPINndO5uQxCmVzVKFM_tAbkvxyy_bNnM/edit?usp=sharing

iPhone had a hegemony on the phone industry for years.  Net sales have declined due to innovation and competition in the market. Most phones are sold in China and I believe the trade wars between the US and China will affect sales. FOXCONN, the largest manufacturer of Iphones has begun to diversify its portfolio because they are expecting sales of the iPhone to slow.

Apple's 4Q 10-K filing identifies lower iPhone sales in 2020 than 2019 due to 1) fewer models; 2) store closings; 3) exchange rates impacting non-US sales.  
1) Fewer models: I agree with @tfk. More models will allow apple to reach more consumers (but possibly hurt margins).
2) FY 2021 will hopefully see fewer lockdowns than 2020. Also, I expect FY2020 caused a lot of people to defer upgrading or purchasing a new iPhone. This might push people to upgrade in FY2021. 
3) Exchange rates and sales in developing countries will be something to monitor into the future. IMO, this is not an important factor impacting sales in FY2021.  Baseline assumptions: 
#1) The number of smartphones sold each year is increasing slowly (https://www.statista.com/statistics/263437/global-smartphone-sales-to-end-users-since-2007/#:~:text=This%20statistic%20shows%20the%20number,with%20the%20Android%20operating%20system). If trends were constant, we'd expect FY2021 to be ~6 percent higher than 2019 (Covid-19 and a global slowdown may be negative headwinds). This forecast will monitor consumer spending throughout the end of 2020 and 2021 and update accordingly. 
#2) Apple's markets hare will remain unchanged as premium smartphone users opt to upgrade from existing iPhones. Apple commands a relatively stable share of the overall smartphone market at between 10 and 18 percent (https://www.counterpointresearch.com/global-smartphone-share/).
4 new iPhone models will ship early in FY21 with the potential for an addtl launch of a “13” model back on a more normalized launch schedule (ie Sept) that would also be captured in late FY2-

Corona and long home stays for Apple users.
@- @------ @11Qrichard
Economic recovery global in 2021 will boost sales.

https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/apple-q4-earnings-reaction-iphone-sales-miss-services-mac-growth-2020-10-1029747745#
Wedbush: 'On the cusp of its largest iPhone cycle' since 2014 "Though iPhone weakness drove Friday's sell-off, investors can rest assured that the new lineup will drive strong sales through the current quarter, Wedbush's Dan Ives said. Preorder activity is tracking at double the rate seen during last year's iPhone release, suggesting the 5G-capable lineup is "off to a robust start," he said.
Couple the strong start with the roughly 350 million iPhone users due for an upgrade, and Apple seems to be "on the cusp of its largest iPhone cycle since iPhone 6 in 2014," Ives said, adding that investors disappointed by the Thursday report should scoop up shares on any weakness."
I'll start here, wait for crowd input, do a little research... get down tonight.

Just looking at the FY20 vs FY19 makes this seem possible to me. Whether people are stuck at home, or when the vaccine becomes mass produced, the people are ready for 5g. I account for the lay-offs and how hard a lot of people will get hit. I still think people make space for this purchase, especially with a possible post-vaccine boom. Looking at an average of $800 per phone, it looks like there will be a requirement for about 5.7m units. This was not in-depth analysis, so will look into this. I may have over-egged here, yet I'll be watching the quarterly's with interest.
